Author: illicium
Content:
Yep, #1 is a quite popular and highly rated idea for Topaz (GNOME 3.0) over at Gnome-Look: http://gnome-look.org/content/show.php/May-B?content=45837

By the way, if anyone likes #3, it can be easily pieced together with:

* Mire v2 GTK theme (http://gnome-look.org/content/show.php/Mire+v2+themepack?con...) with the included Emerald window decorator theme

* area o.42 icons (http://gnome-look.org/content/show.php/area+o.42+SVG+icon+th...)

* gnome2-globalmenu (http://code.google.com/p/gnome2-globalmenu/) for the OS X unified menu bar

Author: wumi
Content:
"Should we expect Scribd’s traffic to take a nosedive? Unlikely. Porn may have helped Scribd gain momentum in its infancy, but the site has long since proven its use as a blogging tool and a document repository. If anything, it’s surprising that it took Scribd this long to make the switch."

so will Justin.tv ban illegal broadcasts as well?

seems the somewhat successful strategy for building content on these community apps is allowing either illegal or unscrupulous behavior to build traffic, and then nix it when you're big enough to survive on your own.

Is this the strategy PG recommends, or the YC founders just think of it on their own?

Author: jamesjyu
Content: Unless you have massive engineering resources that's not dedicated to feature enhancements and new developments of your main product (ie. a small startup environment), a full rewrite is just too expensive.

Author: jamesjyu
Content:
I took several courses at Stanford with Julius Smith (the author of this ebook). He's really sharp, and explains complicated audio signal processing concepts very well. If you're even remotely interested in pursuing research in audio technologies, I would highly recommend the CCRMA program at stanford.

http://ccrma.stanford.edu/

Author: dcurtis
Content: I had no idea that brochures were made for these types of things. Who is the target reader?

Author: xenoterracide
Title: PG Essay Suggestion: an essay about each YC startup
Content:
"This is a bit tangential: Every start-up that YC funds is potentially worth an essay. Isn't that why they are funded? They solve a problem that nags many." --ChaitanyaSai http://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=192730

I think it would be interesting to see what PG thinks about the startups they fund.

Why pg and the others at YC picked those of the groups they interviewed; what about the product was it they liked; what wasn't right; how did they see the people and product grow; etc, etc.

I of course understand this would be a lot of work. But it would be quite interesting. It might be easiest to start with the current group and keep a journal on them, and refine it after the current period is done and then publish.
